title: The Power of the Daleks
dialogue_triumphs: The Doctor on the Daleks: 'It can do many things, Lesterson. But the thing it does most efficiently is exterminate human beings.'
goofs: In one of the existing clips a Dalek has trouble getting through an archway.
There is obvious usage of Dalek photo blow-ups.

continuity_notes.name: The Second Doctor
continuity_notes.description: The newly regenerated incarnation of the Doctor, experiencing his first adventure.
continuity_notes.current_status: Adjusting to his new body and personality after regeneration.

continuity_notes.name: TARDIS
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's time and space machine.
continuity_notes.current_status: Implied to have a role in the Doctor's regeneration process.

continuity_notes.name: Daleks
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's most notorious enemies, cyborg beings driven by hatred.
continuity_notes.current_status: Recognize the Doctor despite his new face, become dormant without static electricity.

continuity_notes.name: Ben
continuity_notes.current_status: Skeptical about the Doctor's new incarnation.

technobabble: Vulcan has 'Oxygen density 172, radiation nil, temperature 86, strong suggestion of mercury deposits'.
Daleks know chemical formulae for sulphuric acid and sodium ethoxide.
roots: Rouben Mamoulian's 1931 version of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde (the Doctor's transformation)
links: The Doctor finds Saladin's dagger ('The Crusade') and a key to a Dalek door made of dalekanium in the TARDIS chest.
Brief mention of 'Marco Polo' ('China, I went there once').

locations.name: Vulcan
locations.description: The planet where the story takes place, not related to Star Trek's Vulcan.
locations.current_status: Setting for the main events of the story, pre-2164.

untold_adventures: The Doctor's previous visit to China, possibly during the time of Marco Polo.
qv: The First History of the Daleks
additional_notes: This story marks the first regeneration of the Doctor, a crucial moment in the series' history.
bottom_line: 'When I say run, run like a rabbit!' The first, and most important, reformatting of Doctor Who's central character is carried out with considerable style.
